p: The micro-emultocrit technique (MET) was first described by Macedo, Fernandes,[32] as an appropriate tool to evaluate and predict influences provided by small variations in the HLB values on emulsions. Thus, besides the simplicity, the ability to use a low amount of sample and with a short time of execution made this method an excellent tool to evaluate and/or optimize formulation parameters and their respective HLB values. The results of the short term stability study are shown in Figure 4. Regarding the creaming index data, the lowest CI rates were observed at time D1 for the formulations F3, F4, F5 and F6, where CI were 3.62%, 3.43%, 3.47%, and 3.51%, respectively. After 30 days (D30), lower CI were observed for F1, F2, F3, F4, and F5 (2.42%, 1.88%; 1.81%; 1.83% and 1.78%, respectively). And, on the last day of analysis (D90), the CI for F1, F2, F3 and F4 were 2.43%, 1.75%; 2.9%, and 1.73% respectively.
